title: American_Top_40_1972_March_18th
description:
American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Casey tells the story of a singer in the countdown who, to get a record deal, once rented an expensive studio and hired 25 musicians with a conductor, without having any money to pay for it.

Casey remebers the group who once occupied the top five spots on the chart at the same time. He calls it an unbreakable record.

One listener wants to know, "What was the biggest selling record that never reached the top 40?"

"American Pie" by Don Mclean goes on for 8 minutes and 22 seconds. As of March, 1972 it was the longest song to ever reach number one. It would only be in the countdown one more week, so in this broadcast, Casey plays the long version.

Casey answers the question, "Did anyone ever have a number one record with their first hit, and then never have another hit after that?" This would be one of the few questions where the answer doesn't involve the Beatles or Elvis! Casey says it's happened five times.
